title: (x) Typeface with ancient greek characteristics - various {gang}
content:
Please help, I'm looking for a full english alphabetical font that has a an ancient greek appearance similar to the following. Could someone make some suggestions, thanks!   
   
 [http://www.phoenixrisingcharlotte.net/images/Phoenix\_Rising\_logo.gif](http://web.archive.org/web/20050818134338/http:/www.phoenixrisingcharlotte.net/images/Phoenix_Rising_logo.gif)   
   
or the 2004 Olympic Banner in   
   
 [http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/olympics/2004/](http://web.archive.org/web/20050818134338/http:/sportsillustrated.cnn.com/olympics/2004/)
author: trunk

comments.content:
Your second sample is similar to [lithos](http://web.archive.org/web/20050818134338/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/lithos/), but lithos is kind of a cliche in this context.   
   
Look at the suggestions in [this thread](http://web.archive.org/web/20050818134338/http:/www.typophile.com/cgibin/discus.pl?pg=next&topic=83&page=11974).
You can also take a look at [Acropolis Now](http://web.archive.org/web/20050818134338/http:/www.p22.com/products/acropolis.html) or later.

You could also see [Phoenikia](http://web.archive.org/web/20050818134338/http:/www.veer.com/products/typedetail.aspx?image=LFT2354400) from Letraset, or [Pompeia](http://web.archive.org/web/20050818134338/http:/www.unifonts.com/intropag/p_intro.htm) (serif or sans) from Unifonts.   
   
These probably fit the cliche category, but I think at least these avoid the pseudo-Greek Latin lettering of Acropolis at P22.
